prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Thomas Ritchie Correspondence, 1835-1853. Accession 28545, Personal papers collection, The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Thomas Ritchie was born on 5 November 1778 in Tappahannock, Essex County, Virginia, the son of Archibald and Mary (Roane) Ritchie. He opened a bookstore in Richmond, Virginia in 1803. On 9 May 1804, he co- founded the Richmond Enquirer with W. W. Worsley and became the sole editor and owner a year later. From 1814-1834, 1835-1839, Ritchie served as the state printer and in 1845 was elected congressional printer. At the behest of President James K. Polk, he founded the Washington Union in 1845. Ritchie died in Washington, D.C. on 2 July 1854.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, 1835-1853 and undated, to Thomas Ritchie, from various individuals concerning politics, newspapers, and slavery.

did.unittitle: Jno. O. Lay, Congress Hall, Saratoga, to Thos. Ritchie, Esq., Enq[uire]r office, Richmond, 8 August 1835
did.abstract: Describing his meeting with Van Buren, in which they discussed abolition.

did.unittitle: N. M. Martin, Petersburg, to Thos. Ritchie, Esq., Richmond, 7 October 1843
did.abstract: Discussing the strength of the Republican [Democratic] Party and the convention to nominate its Presidential candidate.

did.unittitle: J. T. Barbour, Catalpa, to T. Ritchie, Esq., 24 July 1845
did.abstract: Discussing Calhoun and his influence in keeping the Republican [Democratic] Party intact, and also, the Senate and party strength within it.

did.unittitle: E. W. Brown, Platte City, Missouri, to [Thomas Ritchie], Washington Union, Washington City, D. C., 2 February 1847
did.abstract: Discussing his "plan for the navigation of the atmosphere by means of the balloon," and desiring to publish his plan so that someone might test it.

did.unittitle: J. T. Barbour, Catalpa, to T. Ritchie, Esq., 29 April 1847
John Marshall, Mississippian office, to Hon. Thomas Ritchie, Washington, D. C., 9 May 1848
did.abstract: Taking exception to Ritchie's position regarding slavery in California.

did.unittitle: John K. Martin, Colemans Hotel, to Thos. Ritchie, Esq., Washington City, D. C., 30 July 1848
did.abstract: Sending F. R. Blair's statement of his position on Van Buren, Lewis Cass, and William O. Butler.

did.unittitle: John Marshall, New Orleans, to Hon. Thomas Ritchie, 30 September 1848
John Marshall, Jackson, Mississippi, to Hon. Thos. Ritchie, 29 June 1849
did.abstract: Praising Ritchie's management of the Union [paper] and telling of his own purchase of the Mississippian

did.unittitle: Samuel Treat, St. Louis, to Thomas Ritchie, Esq., Washington, D. C., 30 July 1849
did.abstract: Concerning a man to succeed Capt. Phillips as editor of the St. Louis Union, and also discussing Benton's waning political power.

did.unittitle: W[illia]m Goodwin, Louisa Courthouse, to Mr. Thomas Ritchie, former editor of the R[ichmond] Enquirer,26 May 1853
did.abstract: Requesting information on inquiry procedures concerning the estates of Scottish nobility.

did.unittitle: W[illiam] L[earned] M[arcey], [Secretary of War], to Mr. Tho. Ritchie, ca. 1848-1849
did.abstract: Returning two letters Ritchie had sent - (1) John R. MacMurdo, Treasurer of U. S. Mint, New Orleans, to John Marshall, Esq., concerning the New Orleans Quartermaster's political views, 27 September 1848 (2 p., Ms. copy) and (2) Peter K. Magnus, editor of New Orleans Courier, New Orleans, to J. Marshall, Esq., concerning the New Orleans Quartermaster's political conduct, 27 September 1848 (2 p., Ms. copy)
